citations.narrative:
Two outdoor enclosures, one that housed pigeons and the other housing macaws, had perches of inadequate shape or
size for the species. Only one perch per enclosure was of adequate size and shape for the birds contained within. The
other perches provided were too large in diameter which caused the birds to hold their feet in an abnormal conformation.
Failure to provide species appropriate perches may result in injury to the birds such as development of foot sores and can
contribute to their discomfort. Furniture-type objects such as perches must be species appropriate and designed and
maintained so that they prevent harm to the bird.
Correct by 04/15/2025.
Corrected at time of inspection.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The indoor enclosure housing cockatoos and parrots is in need of cleaning. The back wall and ceiling heaters are dirty
and covered by a layer of dust and debris. Numerous cobwebs were located along the back wall up to the ceiling of the
enclosure. Regular cleaning is necessary to prevent soiling of the birds, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests
and odors. The facility must establish a system for timely removal of dust, debris, as well as excreta as necessary to
prevent excessive accumulation within the enclosures.
Correct by 04/15/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two outdoor enclosures, one that housed pigeons and the other housing macaws, had perches of inadequate shape or 
size for the species. Only one perch per enclosure was of adequate size and shape for the birds contained within. The 
other perches provided were too large in diameter which caused the birds to hold their feet in an abnormal conformation. 
Failure to provide species appropriate perches may result in injury to the birds such as development of foot sores and can 
contribute to their discomfort. Furniture-type objects such as perches must be species appropriate and designed and 
maintained so that they prevent harm to the bird. 
Correct by 04/15/2025. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The indoor enclosure housing cockatoos and parrots is in need of cleaning. The back wall and ceiling heaters are dirty 
and covered by a layer of dust and debris. Numerous cobwebs were located along the back wall up to the ceiling of the 
enclosure. Regular cleaning is necessary to prevent soiling of the birds, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests 
and odors. The facility must establish a system for timely removal of dust, debris, as well as excreta as necessary to 
prevent excessive accumulation within the enclosures.  
Correct by 04/15/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
